_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FACILITY DESCRIPTION

	The Table Rock Gas Plant is owned and operated by Chevron Production Company. The Gas Plant was shut down in 2009 and significant equipment inspection, reconditioning and equipment replacement was completed to bring the Plant up to Chevron expectations for Plant equipment mechanical integrity and operability. Operations were started back up in October 2009. 
	
	The gas plant, located in the Table Rock gas field (approx. 45 miles east of Rock Springs, Wyoming), is configured to process 10-60 mmscfd of natural occurring hydrocarbon gas and natural gas liquids.
	
	Chevron has approximatel20-36 employees, and contractors working for the Asset.  Consisting of Operations, Maintenance and support staff 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

It is the policy of Chevron USA Production Company to conduct its business in a socially responsible and ethical manner that protects safety, health and the environment in accordance with the Chevron Way. The TRGP Emergency Preparedness and Response Policy involves assessing the hazards and risks of an unplanned incident; developing a plan for managing those hazards and risks; communicating relevant information to employees, contractors and appropriate agencies; and conducting emergency exercises.

PRIMARY ACTIVITIES

Gas Processing Unit

	Sour natural occurring hydrocarbon gas from approx 11 wells is gathered at the Plant Inlet and compressed to processing pressure for further processing in the gas plant.

Hydrocarbon Liquids and produced water are separated from the gas stream upstream of the compression facility.

The liquid hydrocarbons are batch shipped by truck and sold on the market. The produced water is treated and injected down hole in a permitted injection well.

The H2S/CO2 Removal system is designed to remove H2S/CO2 from the naturally occurring hydrocarbon gases from the Plant inlet. 

The sour gas stream is fed to the H2S Contactor for contacting with a MDEA solution. H2S/CO2 is abso

rbed into the MDEA.

The MDEA is regenerated to produce a gas stream containing H2S, CO2 and water vapor (steam), which is further processed for conversion to elemental sulfur in the SRU. 

The regenerated MDEA is re-circulated to the H2S Contactor.

The Natural Gas is refrigerated in the Propane/Glycol refrigeration equipment to control the Sales Gas dew point to pipeline specifications.

The Sales Gas is then delivered into the Sales Gas Pipeline for marketing.

Sulfur Recovery Unit

The H2S liberated from the MDEA is reacted and converted to elemental sulfur utilizing the Claus Sulfur Recovery process (SRU)

Elemental Sulfur is recovered for sales and shipped to market by tank truck. 


ABS/ATS Tail Gas Unit

Tail Gas from the SRU is incinerated and the remaining H2S is converted to SO2.

Anhydrous ammonia is introduced to the Tail Gas stream and reacts with the SO2 to produce an ABS solution. (Ammonium biosulphide)

The ABS solution and Tail Gas is reacted in the Tail Gas Unit equipment.

Ammonium thiosulfate (liquid fertilizer) is produced from the reaction and stored for marketing in the ATS Storage Tank.

The ATS is shipped to market by tank truck or rail car.

The Tail Gas from the Plant is then lofted to the atmosphere via the Tail Gas Stack at or below Wyoming State DEQ permitted levels for emission components.

REGULATED SUBSTANCES ABOVE THRESHOLD QUANTITIES AT TRGP

There are two RMP defined processes with threshold quantities of regulated substances at TRGP including:

Process 1: Flammables

Inlet flows and quantities of flammable, naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixtures of methane, ethane, propane, butane, pentane and H2S. The total quantities found in the process vessels, process piping, storage bullets and miscellaneous equipment above the threshold limit.


Process 2: Toxics

Anhydrous Ammonia is delivered by rail car and off loaded into the Anhydrous Ammonia storage vessel for use in the ABS/ATS Tail Gas Unit in quantities above the threshold limi

t.


THE WORST CASE SENARIOS

Process 1: Flammables

Worst-case scenario (WCS) would be a loss of containment of a Liquid Hydrocarbon storage  vessel contents, releasing the entire vessel volume resulting in a liquid hydrocarbon spill and weathering release of hydrocarbon vapors and a flash fire.  Although Chevron has numerous controls to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating this scenario. While the calculated maximum distance to endpoint (1 psi overpressure) for the WCS of Process 1 is beyond the plant boundaries, there are no public receptors within that calculated radius due to the remote location of the gas plant


Process 2- Toxics

The Worst-Case release Scenario (WCS) for toxic substances is loss of containment of the storage vessel, V-305 which contains quantities above the threshold limit of Anhydrous Ammonia. This scenario assumes that the entire contents of this vessel are released in 10 minutes.

Although Chevron has numerous controls to prevent such a release and to manage their 
consequences, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation measures was taken 
into account in evaluating this scenario. While the calculated maximum distance to the toxic 
end point for the WCS of Process 2 is beyond the plant boundaries, there are no public receptors 
within that calculated radius due to the remote location of the gas plant. There is a normally 
unoccupied third party storage and telecom equipment building with access un-controlled by 
TRGP which is located within the toxic end point for this release scenario.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Chevron encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents, operating procedures, job safety analyses and compiling chemical i

nformation to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis team.

Employees have access to all information created as part of the TRGP accident prevention program element. 

The TRGP keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories and equipment design basis/configuration information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).

TRGP is operated and maintained within design specifications, standards and limits set and accepted by the industry and (or) Company.

The processes are controlled and monitored using instruments, trained personnel and protective systems (e.g. distributive control systems, automated detection, emergency shutdown systems, closed blowdown systems, pressure relief valves, pressure control valves, remotely located flare system, etc.).

TRGP has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined with appropriate hazards analysis methodologies to identify hazards and that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

TRGP maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, and (5) normal shutdown. 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Chevron has implemented a training program for all employees involved in operating TRGP

TRGP uses Management of change processes to control and track Facility changes 

Mechanical Integrity programs including on-line equipment testing (e.g. ultrasonic thickness testing, corrosion coupons, etc.), chemical inhibi

tion to control corrosion, equipment preventative maintenance and the regularly scheduled comprehensive internal equipment inspection and repair.

THE FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No accidental releases have occurred at this Facility in the past 5 years

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The RM program at this facility consists of three (3) elements:  
1) A hazard assessment to help understand the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental releases, 

2) A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate the processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance (covered processes).

3) An emergency response program to help respond to accidental releases of regulated substances from covered processes.
                                                                                               
This facility has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing many levels of safeguards or controls against release of a hazardous substance and injuries and damage to its employees, the public, and the environment. We limit the use of hazardous substances.  Before using a hazardous substance, less hazardous alternatives are considered.  When a hazardous substance is used, consideration is given to the potential for this substance to adversely affect our workers, the public, and the environment, and we take steps to prevent any such effects.

Emergency Response procedures are regularly reviewed with personnel working on site and Emergency Response drills are conducted to test and practice the procedures.

The safety program consists of a number of elements, only some of which are required by the RMP rule.  There are other prevention programs which are company specific and those required by the Department of Transportation under parts 192 or 195 and OSHA under the PSM regulation

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE
We are committed to the safety of workers and the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental

releases of hazardous substances.  This facility implements reasonable prevention programs to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  These controls include training programs for personnel; programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes; and programs to evaluate the hazards at this facility.

In the event of an accidental release, we control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injury to the public or the environment.  This facility coordinates response efforts with the local emergency response personnel located in Wammsuter and Rock Springs Wyoming.
